metadata.title: Heterogenization of ionic liquid based on mesoporous material as magnetically recyclable catalyst for biodiesel production

IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9364 S1381-1169(14)00540-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.12.002 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 The schematic representation of the synthetic route of FSS–IL and the application in esterification of oleic acid for biodiesel production. Fig. 2 Representative SEM images (a, c, e) and TEM images (b, d, f) of FSS (a, b), FSS–IL(c, d), and recovered FSS–IL(e, f). Fig. 3 Wide-angle XRD patterns of Fe3O4, FSS, and FSS–IL. Fig. 4 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of FSS, FSS–IL, and recovered FSS–IL. Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra of Fe3O4, FSS, IL, and FSS–IL. Fig. 6 Magnetic hysteresis loops of FSS and FSS–IL. Inset was the schematic representation of the separation of FSS–IL. Fig. 7 Optimization of FSS–IL-catalyzed esterification of oleic acid: reaction temperature (a), (4h, 6:1, 10.6 wt%); reaction time (b), (383K, 6:1, 10.6wt%); alcohol/oleic acid molar ratio (c), (4h, 383K, 10.6wt%); catalyst amount (d), (4h, 383K, 6:1). Fig. 8 Reusability of FSS–IL. Fig. 9 The mechanism of esterification catalyzed by FSS–IL catalyst. Table 1 Performances of various catalysts for esterification of oleic with short alcohols a Oleic Acid+Alcohol⇌Biodiesel+Water. Entry Catalyst Alcohol Catalysis type Catalyst separation Separation time (min) Catalyst massloss (wt%) b Yield (%) 1 Blank Ethanol – – – – 5.2 2 H2SO4 Ethanol Homogeneous Chemical reaction+skimming >10 100 90.1 3 FSS Ethanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 1.2 6.4 4 IL Ethanol Homogeneous Distillation+skimming >30 15.6 94.2 5 FSS–IL Methanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 1.5 89.6 6 FSS–IL Ethanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 1.3 93.5 7 FSS–IL c Ethanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 2.6 87.4 8 FSS–IL n-Propanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 1.8 92.0 9 FSS–IL n-Butanol Heterogeneous Magnetic field <1 1.6 91.5 a Reaction conditions: n alcohol:n oleicacid =6:1; temperature, 383K; time, 4h; catalyst amount (based on oleic acid) 10.6wt%. b Catalyst mass loss was calculated based on the first run except Entry 7. c The 6th run. Heterogenization of ionic liquid based on mesoporous material as magnetically recyclable catalyst for biodiesel production Hui Wan Zuowang Wu Wen Chen Guofeng Guan ⁎ Yuan Cai Chong Chen Zhong Li Xiaoqin Liu State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 25 8358 7198. Graphical abstract The combination of nano-Fe3O4, mesoporous silica and acidic ionic liquid made an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the biodiesel production. To develop green and reusable catalysts for the biodiesel preparation, a novel magnetically separable nanocatalyst was fabricated by covalent bonding of 3-sulfopropyl-1-(3-propyltrimethoxysilane) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([SO3H-PIM-TMSP]HSO4) on mesoporous silica modified Fe3O4 nanoparticle. The catalyst possessed uniform core-shell structure with magnetic response core and Brønsted ionic liquid functionalized mesoporous silica shell. The multifunctional catalyst also exhibited appealing physicochemical features like high specific surface area, mesoporous channel, magnetic response, and fine catalytic activity in esterification of oleic acid with alcohol. Under mind conditions, the conversion of oleic acid was up to 93.5%. The catalyst exhibited recyclable property based on magnetism and the separation of the catalyst would be simply using external magnetic field without obvious mass loss, allowing a clean biodiesel product. Keywords Ionic liquid Magnetic Heterogeneous catalyst Biodiesel 1 Introduction Biodiesel has been a modern and technological area due to the relevance to environmental benefits and the increasing in the petroleum price. As an alternative diesel fuel derived from vegetable oils, animal fats, and microalgae etc., biodiesel is biodegradable, renewable, and nontoxic, having low emission profiles [1,2]. Generally, both of the transesterification of triglycerides (TGs) with alkaline catalysts and esterification of free fatty acids (FFAs) with acidic catalysts can be applied to prepare biodiesel. But alkaline catalysts require anhydrous conditions and feed stocks with low levels of FFAs to avoid saponification [3]. In that situation, many approaches involving acid catalysis have been developed [4]. Specially, heterogeneous acid catalysts have played the important role for green and recyclable catalysts [5,6]. Recently, ionic liquid has become a new eco-benign approach toward modern chemistry, having found applications in a wide range of areas, including catalysis, synthesis, analysis, and gas absorption, etc., [7], especially those functionalized with Lewis and/or Brønsted acid sites [8,9]. The ionic liquid, with the properties of flexibility, non-volatility, non-corrosivity, and immiscibility with many organic solvents, can afford higher yields and selectivities with potential application in replacing conventionally homogeneous/heterogeneous acid catalysts [10]. It has been reported that esterification of oleic acid can be catalyzed by functionalized ionic liquid with satisfied yield [11,12]. However, several drawbacks like unsuitable viscosity, tedious separation procedures, and large dosage in catalysis, hamper their widespread applications. As separation and recycle of catalysts are critically required to reduce the cost of catalysts as well as to avoid the generation of waste, it requires the heterogenization of ionic liquid [13]. Based on the facts that the chemical and structural versatility of ionic liquid make them potential guest molecule candidates for the post-functionalization of solid materials [14], supported ionic liquid (SIL) is prepared by immobilizing IL on solid material [15,16]. The supported ionic liquid has better performance in many fields, with the merits of both homogeneous ionic liquid and heterogeneous solid materials [17,18]. To develop efficient and recyclable catalysts, nano-magnetite has been developed as a new support with the properties of easy synthesis and functionalization, facile separation by magnetic force [19,20]. At the same time, ordered mesoporous materials have been widely used in adsorption, separation, catalysis, etc., due to the unique properties and functionalities [21]. Thus the introduction of magnetic nanoparticles in mesoporous materials realizes the combination of ionic liquid heterogenization with techniques for magnetic separation [22,23]. Magnetite-supported ionic liquid catalysts are an important and growing arena in heterogeneous catalysis, having been successfully applied in numerous important reactions [24,25]. In this work, we design and prepare a magnetic mesoporous material Fe3O4@SiO2@mSiO2 (FSS) supported ionic liquid [SO3H-PIM-TMSP]HSO4 (IL) catalyst, defined as FSS–IL, for biodiesel production. Magnetic mesoporous support FSS is fabricated with super magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticle as core and silica layers as shells. The inner silica layer of FSS acts as the surface protector and the outer mesoporous silica shell works as the support, which benefits the diffusion of guest molecules and improves mass transfer. The catalyst is systematically characterized and applied in heterogeneous catalytic esterification of oleic acid, allowing a clean biodiesel product and easy catalyst removal from the reaction mixture under magnetic force. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Material and instruments Ethylene glycol, ethanol, imidazole, sulfuric acid, anhydrous FeCl3, toluene, 1,3-propane sultone, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), sodium acetate anhydrous, sodium citrate, ethyl silicate (TEOS), γ-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (CPMS), oleic acid (85%), diethyl ether, ammonium hydroxide were commercially available and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were gained by a S4800 Field-emission scanning electron Microscope (HITACHI, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with a JEM-2100 (HR) (JEOL, Japan), and the samples were daubed onto carbon film supported on copper grids for analysis. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Smartlab diffractometer (RIGAKU, Japan). Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured by a Nicolet-6700 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States) using anhydrous KBr as dispersing agent. N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system model instrument. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) algorithm. The mesoporous pore size distribution was obtained through the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) theory. The magnetic hysteresis loops were measured by a lakeshore 7407 vibrating sample magnetometer (China Trend Limited, China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation Brønsted ionic liquid 1-(propyl-3-sulfonate)-3-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate [SO3H-PIM-TMSP][HSO4] was prepared referring to the previous published article [26]: imidazole (0.05mol) was dissolved in ethanol and equimolar sodium ethylate was added afterwards. The reaction was carried out at 348K for 12h. 3-Chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (0.05mol) was added dropwise and the mixture was stirred for another 12h in N2 atmosphere. After the generated sodium chloride was removed, 1,3-propane sultone (0.05mol) was added and stirred at 323K for 12h. Sulfuric acid (0.05mol) was added, reacting at the same temperature for 6h. [SO3H-PIM-TMSP][HSO4] was achieved by washing with diethyl ether and drying under vacuum. The magnetic Fe3O4 microspheres were synthesized by a solvothermal reaction [27]. By the hydrolysis and condensation of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) in the mixture of water, ethanol and ammonia, individual Fe3O4 microsphere was coated with uniform silica layer, generating Fe3O4@SiO2 microsphere. With TEOS as silica source and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as structure-directing agent, a CTAB/silica composite layer was formed on the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2 microsphere. Magnetic FSS mesoporous microspheres were gained after CTAB was removed [28]. The catalyst FSS–IL was prepared as following. IL (1.5g) and FSS (1.0g) was dissolved in dry toluene (50ml). The mixture was heated to reflux for 24h in N2 atmosphere. FSS–IL catalyst was obtained after washing with diethyl ether and drying in vacuum at 323K for 8h. The total synthetic route of FSS–IL was represented in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement Biodiesel production from oleic acid with alcohol was carried out with FSS–IL as catalyst. In a typical run, oleic acid (10mmol), alcohol (60mmol), and catalyst (0.2g) were added in a flask (50ml) and kept under 373K for 4h. When the reaction was finished, a magnet was put at the bottom of the reaction flask and the catalyst would be totally adsorbed to the magnet. The upper layer was dumped out for analysis and the yield of biodiesel was calculated based on oleic acid referring to previous publication [11]. The left catalyst was washed with acetone for three times, setting in vacuum at 323K for 6h for recycling experiment. The recovered catalyst was also weighted by electronic balance (d =0.0001g) for calculating catalyst mass loss data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization According to the SEM/TEM images, the FSS particle (Fig. 2 a) exhibited good monodispersity and uniform spherical morphology. A core-shell structure with Fe3O4 core and two distinct silica layers was clearly shown in the TEM images (Fig. 2b,d,f). The inner shell was fabricated as non-porous silica with a thickness of ∼40nm, with the purpose of protecting Fe3O4 core from decay in some harsh reaction circumstances. The mesoporous channels in the outer shell provided the main area for immobilizing IL and favored the access of guest molecules, serving as nanoreactors. The morphology and structure of recovered FSS–IL catalyst (Fig. 2e and f) had no obvious change when compared with the fresh (Fig. 2c and d), indicating the good stability and high corrosion resistance against acidic reaction environment. The wide-angel XRD pattern of magnetic Fe3O4 microsphere (Fig. 3 ) exhibited six distinct peaks, which matched well with previous report on crystalline magnetic microspheres [29]. The extra-large shoulder centered at around 2theta=23° was attributed to the silica component. The XRD results indicated that the magnetic core Fe3O4 was well retained in the silica matrix, consistent with the TEM results (Fig. 2). The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of FSS showed characteristic type IV curve (Fig. 4 ), indicating a mesoporous structure. The BET surface areas of FSS, FSS–IL, and recovered FSS–IL were calculated to be 547m2/g, 175m2/g, and 168m2/g, respectively. Based on the uniformly interpenetrating mesopore and large surface area, FSS could interact with guest IL not only at the external surface, but also through the whole internal pore system. The decrease of FSS–IL surface area was caused due to the immobilization of ionic liquid when compared with FSS. Recovered FSS–IL showed similar curve when compared with fresh FSS–IL, and the slight surface area decrease might be caused by the adsorption of organic molecules and the drop of the order degree of structure. Successful immobilization of IL on FSS could also be inferred from the results of FT-IR in Fig. 5 . Band around 580cm−1 were assigned to the FeO stretching. The SiOSi stretching modes of the silica shell could be observed as a strong peak around 1088cm−1. The IR curve of IL showed typical bands at 1168 and 1054cm−1 (SO asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations), 2940, 2864 and 1458cm−1 (alkyl chain stretching and deformation vibrations), 1564cm−1 (CN and CC vibrations of the imidazole ring) [30]. In the spectrum of FSS–IL, the characteristic peaks were at the same wavenumbers, proving that IL were successfully supported on FSS. Magnetic properties were tested and the saturation magnetization values were 20.6emu/g and 13.2emu/g for FSS and FSS–IL, respectively (Fig. 6 ). The decrease of saturation magnetization value was caused by the layer of supported ionic liquid. No hysteresis loop and remanence were detected for both of the samples. The superparamagentic property afforded the easy separation of FSS–IL after reaction by simply using a magnet (Fig. 6 inset). 3.2 FSS–IL for biodiesel production FSS–IL was applied in the esterification of oleic acid with ethanol and univariate analysis was applied to research the influence of reaction temperature, time, alcohol/acid molar ratio, and catalyst amount on the yield of biodiesel. A high value of 93.5% was achieved when temperature reached 383K (Fig. 7 a), which might be due to the increase of the reaction rate and decrease of the mass transfer limitation between reactants and catalyst. As esterification was reversible, the equilibrium was arrived around 4h (Fig. 7b). As excess alcohol would favor the forward reaction [31], experiments with different alcohol/oleic acid molar ratios were carried out and the results was shown in Fig. 7c. As the molar ratio increased, a fine biodiesel yield was achieved at 6:1. The effect of catalyst amount on the yield of biodiesel was studied (Fig. 7d). The maximum yield was achieved in the presence of 10.6wt% FSS–IL (based on oleic acid) when enough catalytic active sites were available [32]. Based on the above data, suitable conditions were obtained as follows: reaction temperature, 383K; reaction time, 4h; ethanol to oleic acid molar ratio, 6:1; and catalyst amount, 10.6wt%. Under these conditions, the conversion of oleic acid was 93.5%. The esterification could be carried out under mind conditions and the catalyst could be isolated conveniently and totally in magnetic field, which allowed for a high biodiesel yield and purity. 3.3 Catalytic activity assessment Table 1 summarized the performances of various catalysts for esterification of oleic with short alcohols. Without any catalyst, oleic acid allowed a low conversion due to the autocatalysis itself (Entry 1). When sulfuric acid, IL, and FSS–IL were applied as catalysts, high yields of biodiesel could be obtained. However, when taking catalyst separation, catalyst separation time, and catalyst mass loss into consideration, FSS–IL showed the best catalytic performance due to its easy separation, short separation time, and trace amount of mass loss (Entry 2,4,6). To investigate the universality of FSS–IL, several most common alcohols were applied as raw materials (Entry 5,6,8,9). Satisfactory yields from 89.6% to 93.5% were obtained under the above reaction conditions. The slight difference in carbon chains have no significant effect on the yield. Esterification of methanol gave relatively lower yield compared with other alcohols due to its lower boiling point. As ethanol also could come from biological resource, it would be the best choice for studies and industrial applications. 3.4 Catalyst reusability As recyclability was an important factor for any catalyst, a six-cycle experiment was carried out to check the catalyst performance. FSS–IL was easily separated from the reaction mixture using magnetic field by taking advantage of its high magnetization and no obvious catalyst mass loss was observed. The recovered FSS–IL was washed with acetone for three times. After dried in vacuum, FSS–IL was directly applied in esterification of oleic acid with ethanol (reaction conditions: time, 4h; temperature, 383K; molar ratio, 6:1; and catalyst amount, 10.6wt%) and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . Notably, the catalyst could maintain good catalytic activity even after being reused for six runs, with only a slight decrease from 93.5% to 87.4%. The decrease in catalytic performance might be probably attributed to minor leaching of acidic protons or the adsorption of reactant molecules on the active sites [33]. The catalytic activity no longer decreased after five cycles, indicating the good catalytic property and reusability of FSS–IL. In order to clarify the reaction process, esterification mechanism catalyzed by FSS–IL catalyst was illustrated in Fig. 9 . The process had two key steps, one was the protonation of oleic acid and the other was the nucleophilic attack of the protonated acid by the alcohol. As displayed in Fig. 9, ionic liquid part [SO3H-PIM-TMSP]HSO4 supported the proton, and oleic acid was protonated to generate a carbocation. After the nucleophilic attack of the alcohol molecule to the carbocation, a middle product was generated. When the bond of hydrogen and oxygen of product 5 was broken, biodiesel was formed and catalyst FSS–IL was regenerated. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study reports a novel heterogeneous catalyst FSS–IL based on magnetically mesoporous material and Brønsted acidic ionic liquid. The well-designed catalyst FSS–IL can be used as an efficient catalyst for the esterification of oleic acid with ethanol for biodiesel production, due to its features like large surface area, highly open and ordered mesopore, and high magnetization. The active sites can be fully exposed and a high biodiesel yield of 93.5% can be obtained. Moreover, this FSS–IL catalytic system can be easily recovered via magnetic separation in short time and reused for several runs without losing its catalytic activity, demonstrating the environmental and economic viability. coredata.dc:description: To develop green and reusable catalysts for the biodiesel preparation, a novel magnetically separable nanocatalyst was fabricated by covalent bonding of 3-sulfopropyl-1-(3-propyltrimethoxysilane) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([SO3H-PIM-TMSP]HSO4) on mesoporous silica modified Fe3O4 nanoparticle. The catalyst possessed uniform core-shell structure with magnetic response core and Brønsted ionic liquid functionalized mesoporous silica shell. The multifunctional catalyst also exhibited appealing physicochemical features like high specific surface area, mesoporous channel, magnetic response, and fine catalytic activity in esterification of oleic acid with alcohol. Under mind conditions, the conversion of oleic acid was up to 93.5%. The catalyst exhibited recyclable property based on magnetism and the separation of the catalyst would be simply using external magnetic field without obvious mass loss, allowing a clean biodiesel product.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogenization of ionic liquid based on mesoporous material as magnetically recyclable catalyst for biodiesel production
